Recorded June 27, 2018}} | caption = Official portrait, 2017 }} {{modern liberalism US}} '''Charles Ellis Schumer''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ʃ|uː|m|ər}} {{respell|SHOO|mər}}; born November 23, 1950) is an American politician serving as [[Senate Majority Leader]] since 2021{{Cite web |date=2021-01-20 |title=Sen. Chuck Schumer will be the first Jewish Senate Majority Leader |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/live-update/inauguration-of-joe-biden-and-kamala-harris/sen-chuck-schumer-will-be-the-first-jewish-senate-majority-leader |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210120213345/https://www.pbs.org/newshour/live-update/inauguration-of-joe-biden-and-kamala-harris/sen-chuck-schumer-will-be-the-first-jewish-senate-majority-leader |archive-date=January 20, 2021 |access-date=2021-01-21 |website=[[PBS NewsHour]]|language=en-us}} and the [[Seniority in the United States Senate|senior]] [[United States Senate|United States senator]] from [[New York (state)|New York]] since 1999. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], he has led the [[Senate Democratic Caucus]] since 2017 and was Senate Minority Leader from 2017 to 2021. Schumer is in his fifth Senate term, making him the longest-serving [[List of United States senators from New York|US senator from New York]], having surpassed [[Daniel Patrick Moynihan]] and [[Jacob K. Javits]] in 2023. He is the dean of [[United States congressional delegations from New York|New York's congressional delegation]]. A native of [[Brooklyn]] and a graduate of [[Harvard College]] and [[Harvard Law School]], Schumer was a three-term member of the [[New York State Assembly]] from 1975 to 1980. He served nine terms in the [[United States House of Representatives]] from 1981 to 1999, first representing [[New York's 16th congressional district]] before being redistricted to the [[New York's 10th congressional district|10th congressional district]] in 1983 and [[New York's 9th congressional district|9th congressional district]] 10 years later. In 1998, Schumer was elected to the Senate, defeating three-term [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] incumbent [[Al D'Amato]]. He was reelected in [[2004 United States Senate election in New York|2004]] with 71% of the vote, in [[2010 United States Senate election in New York|2010]] with 66% of the vote, in [[2016 United States Senate election in New York|2016]] with 70% of the vote, and in [[2022 United States Senate election in New York|2022]] with 56% of the vote. Schumer chaired the [[Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee]] from 2005 to 2009, overseeing 14 Democratic gains in the Senate in the [[2006 United States Senate elections|2006]] and [[2008 United States Senate elections|2008 elections]]. He was the third-ranking Democrat in the Senate, behind Senate Majority Leader [[Harry Reid]] and [[Majority Whip]] [[Dick Durbin]]. He served as [[Vice Chairman of the Democratic Caucus|Vice Chair of the Democratic Caucus in the Senate]] from 2007 to 2017{{cite web|url=http://www.democrats.senate.gov/leadership/|title=Leadership – Schumer became Senate Majority Leader, becoming the first Jewish Senate majority leader. As majority leader, Schumer shepherded through the Senate some of the [[Presidency of Joe Biden|Biden administration]]'s major legislative initiatives, such as the [[American Rescue Plan Act of 2021]], the [[Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act]], the [[Inflation Reduction Act of 2022]], the [[CHIPS and Science Act]], the [[Bipartisan Safer Communities Act]], and the [[Respect for Marriage Act]]. Under his leadership, the Senate confirmed the most [[Federal judiciary of the United States|federal judges]] during the first two years of any presidency since [[John F. Schumer enlists famous cousin Amy to pitch guns bill |last=Kim |first=Seung Min |date=June 2, 2018 |work=[[Politico]] |access-date=August 4, 2015 |archive-date=August 19, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150819121829/http://www.politico.com/story/2015/08/chuck-schumer-amy-schumer-gun-control-120934.html |url-status=live }} His ancestors originated from the town of [[Chortkiv]], [[Galicia (Eastern Europe)|Galicia]], in what is now western [[Ukraine]].{{cite news |url=http://jewishinsider.com/10109/schumer-promises-to-protect-the-jewish-way-of-life/ |title=Schumer Promises to Protect Jewish Way of Life |work=[[Jewish Insider]] |date=December 21, 2016 |first=Jacob |last=Kornbluh |author-link=Jacob Kornbluh |access-date=December 21, 2016 |archive-date=April 26, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190426015703/http://jewishinsider.com/10109/schumer-promises-to-protect-the-jewish-way-of-life/ |url-status=live }} Schumer attended Brooklyn public schools, scoring 1600 on the [[SAT]] and graduating as the [[valedictorian]] of [[James Madison High School (Brooklyn)|James Madison High School]] in 1967. He competed for Madison High on the television quiz show ''[[It's Academic]]''.{{cite news|first=Sam|last=Roberts|website=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/05/nyregion/05debate.html|url-access=limited|title=For Schumer, a Chance to Relive a 1960s Quiz Show|date=March 5, 2007|access-date=March 6, 2007|archive-date=February 22, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210222214735/https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/05/nyregion/05debate.html|url-status=live}} He attended [[Harvard College]], where he originally majored in [[chemistry]] before switching to [[social studies]] after volunteering on [[Eugene McCarthy 1968 presidential campaign|Eugene McCarthy's presidential campaign]] in [[1968 United States presidential election|1968]].{{cite web |title=College and Law School (1968–1974) |url=https://www.senate.gov/~schumer/SchumerWebsite/about_chuck/time-popups/time-college.html|publisher=United States Senate|access-date=July 18, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080710112148/https://www.senate.gov/~schumer/SchumerWebsite/about_chuck/time-popups/time-college.html |archive-date=July 10, 2008}} After graduating ''[[magna cum laude]]'' and [[Phi Beta Kappa]] in 1971, Schumer attended [[Harvard Law School]], earning his [[Juris Doctor]] with honors in 1974. He passed the [[New York State Bar Association|New York state bar]] in early 1975, but never practiced law, opting rather for a career in politics.{{cite news|last=Bruni|first=Frank|author-link=Frank Bruni|title=For Schumer, a Decades-Long Drive Toward a Quest for the Senate|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/26/nyregion/1998-campaign-democrat-for-schumer-decades-long-drive-toward-quest-for-senate.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 26, 1998|access-date=July 18, 2008|url-access=limited|page=A1|archive-date=January 25, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210125215251/https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/26/nyregion/1998-campaign-democrat-for-schumer-decades-long-drive-toward-quest-for-senate.html|url-status=live}} ==Early career (1975–1998)== [[File:Schumer-1987-.jpg|thumb|190px|Schumer during the
[[100th United States Congress|100th Congress]]]] In 1974, Schumer ran for and was elected to the [[New York State Assembly]], filling a seat previously held by Schumer's mentor, Congressman [[Stephen Solarz]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/07/nyregion/washington-at-work-side-by-side-by-solarz-and-schumer-a-rivalry.html|title=Washington at Work; Side by Side by Solarz and Schumer: A Rivalry|first=Richard L.|last=Berke|date=April 7, 1991|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=February 19, 2017|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=September 4, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200904093330/https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/07/nyregion/washington-at-work-side-by-side-by-solarz-and-schumer-a-rivalry.html|url-status=live}} Schumer served three terms, from 1975 to 1981, sitting in the [[181st New York State Legislature|181st]], [[182nd New York State Legislature|182nd]] and [[183rd New York State Legislature]]s.{{cite news|url=http://projects.washingtonpost.com/congress/members/s000148/|title=Chuck Schumer|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=April 4, 2008|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080407215329/http://projects.washingtonpost.com/congress/members/s000148/|archive-date=April 7, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=S000148|title=Schumer, Charlie Ellis (Chuck)|work=Biographical Directory of the United States Congress|access-date=April 4, 2008|archive-date=December 11, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121211234439/http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=S000148|url-status=live}}{{cite web|url=https://schumer.senate.gov/SchumerWebsite/about_chuck/time-popups/time-nys_assembly.html|title=About Chuck: Timeline|website=schumer.senate.gov |access-date=April 4, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327024614/http://schumer.senate.gov/SchumerWebsite/about_chuck/time-popups/time-nys_assembly.html |archive-date=March 27, 2008}} In 1980, 16th district [[United States House of Representatives|Congresswoman]] [[Elizabeth Holtzman]] won the Democratic nomination for the [[United States Senate|Senate]] seat of [[United States Republican Party|Republican]] [[Jacob Javits]]. Schumer ran for Holtzman's vacated [[United States House of Representatives|House]] seat and won. He was reelected eight times from the Brooklyn and [[Queens]]-based district, which changed numbers twice in his tenure (it was numbered the 16th from 1981 to 1983, the 10th from 1983 to 1993, and the 9th from 1993). In 1982, as a result of [[redistricting]], Schumer faced a potential matchup with Solarz, but the matchup did not materialize.{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2010/11/steve-solarz-1940-2010-and-the-making-of-senator-schumer-067223|title=Steve Solarz (1940–2010) and the Making of Senator Schumer|work=[[Politico]]|date=November 30, 2010|first=Steve|last=Kornacki|access-date=September 20, 2020|archive-date=January 25, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210125193526/https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2010/11/steve-solarz-1940-2010-and-the-making-of-senator-schumer-067223|url-status=live}} In preparation, Schumer "set about making friends on [[Wall Street]], tapping the city's top law firms and securities houses for campaign donations. 'I told them I looked like I had a very difficult reapportionment fight. If I were to stand a chance of being re-elected, I needed some help,' he would later tell the [[Associated Press]]." Schumer introduced The [[Religious Freedom Restoration Act]] (also known as RFRA) on March 11, 1993.Pub. L. No. 103-141, 107 Stat. 1488 (November 16, 1993), codified at 42 U.S.C. § 2000bb through 42 U.S.C. § 2000bb-4 As a member of the [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|House Judiciary Committee]], Schumer was one of four members of Congress who oversaw the House investigation (leading the Democratic defense of the [[Clinton administration]]),{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/03/us/in-waco-hearings-parties-undergo-a-role-reversal.html | title=In Waco Hearings, Parties Undergo a Role Reversal | first=Neil A. | last=Lewis | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=August 3, 1995 | access-date=February 15, 2017 | archive-date=December 13, 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201213233942/https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/03/us/in-waco-hearings-parties-undergo-a-role-reversal.html | url-status=live }} of the [[Waco siege]] hearings in 1995.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/28/us/house-investigators-visit-texas-to-prepare-for-waco-hearings.html|title=House Investigators Visit Texas To Prepare for Waco Hearings|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 28, 1995|access-date=February 15, 2017|archive-date=September 3, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200903232321/https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/28/us/house-investigators-visit-texas-to-prepare-for-waco-hearings.html|url-status=live}} ==U.S. Senate (1999–present)== [[File:Chuck Schumer 113th Congress.jpg|thumb|190px|Schumer during the
[[107th United States Congress|107th Congress]]]] In 1998, Schumer [[1998 United States Senate election in New York|ran for the Senate]]. He won the Democratic primary with 51% of the vote against [[Geraldine Ferraro]] (21%) and [[Mark Green (New York politician)|Mark Green]] (19%). He received 54% of the vote in the [[general election]],{{cite web|url=http://www.fec.gov/pubrec/fe1998/98senate.htm|title=Federal Elections 98: U.S. Senate Results by State|publisher=[[Federal Election Commission|FEC]]|access-date=March 18, 2010|archive-date=September 25, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120925181108/http://www.fec.gov/pubrec/fe1998/98senate.htm|url-status=live}} defeating three-term [[incumbent]] Republican [[Al D'Amato]] (44%). In 2004, Schumer was reelected with 71% of the vote, defeating the Republican nominee, [[New York Legislature|Assemblyman]] [[Howard Mills]] of [[Middletown, Orange County, New York|Middletown]], and [[Conservative Party of New York|conservative]] Marilyn F. O'Grady. Many New York Republicans were dismayed by the selection of Mills over the conservative [[Michael Benjamin Bonheur|Michael Benjamin]], who held significant advantages over Mills in both fundraising and organization.{{cite web|url=http://www.timesunion.com/AspStories/story.asp?storyID=222422&category=CAPITOL&BCCode=&newsdate=2%2F25%2F2004 |title=Senate hopeful claims GOP bosses snubbed him |author=Benjamin, Elizabeth|access-date=August 7, 2004 |url-status=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040807054126/http://www.timesunion.com/AspStories/story.asp?storyID=222422&category=CAPITOL&BCCode=&newsdate=2%2F25%2F2004 |archive-date=August 7, 2004 }}. ''[[Times Union (Albany)|Albany Times-Union]]'', February 25, 2004. Benjamin publicly accused [[New York Republican State Committee|GOP]] chairman [[Alexander Treadwell|Sandy Treadwell]] and governor [[George Pataki]] of trying to muscle him out of the Senate race and undermine the democratic process. Schumer defeated Mills by 2.8 million votes.{{cite web|url=http://www.benjamin2004.com/press/news/press_051504.asp |title=Major Parties to Anoint their Senate Combatants |access-date=October 27, 2004 |url-status=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041027170724/http://www.benjamin2004.com/press/news/press_051504.asp |archive-date=October 27, 2004 }}. Humbert, Mark. [[Associated Press]], May 15, 2004. He won every county in the state except [[Hamilton County, New York|Hamilton County]], in the [[Adirondacks]], the least populous and most Republican county. In an interview on [[CBS News]]'s ''[[Face the Nation]]'', Schumer said that Gonzales "doesn't accept or doesn't understand that he is no longer just the president's lawyer".{{cite news|last=Goldfarb |first=Zachary |url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/the-talk/2007/03/march_11_schumer_calls_on_gonz.html |title=March 11: Schumer calls on Gonzales to resign |publisher=Blog.washingtonpost.com |access-date=March 18, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523093953/http://blog.washingtonpost.com/the-talk/2007/03/march_11_schumer_calls_on_gonz.html |archive-date=May 23, 2011 }} When Gonzales's chief of staff, [[Kyle Sampson]], resigned on March 13, Schumer said during a press conference that Gonzales was "carrying out the political wishes of the president" and declared that Sampson would "not be the next [[Scooter Libby]]", meaning that he did not accept that Sampson had sole responsibility for the controversy.Archived at [https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211211/pfB_1v1VMv4 Ghostarchive]{{cbignore}} and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20130119103110/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pfB_1v1VMv4 Wayback Machine]{{cbignore}}: {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pfB_1v1VMv4|title=YouTube – Schumer Calls For Gonzales' Resignation|publisher=[[YouTube]]|date=March 13, 2007|access-date=March 18, 2010}}{{cbignore}} Like other members of the [[Senate Judiciary Committee]] from both parties, Schumer was angered during Gonzales's testimony on April 19, 2007; Gonzales answered many times that he did not know or could not recall details about the controversy. When Schumer's turn came to ask his last round of questions, he instead repeated his call for Gonzales to resign, saying that there was no point to further questioning since Gonzales had "answered 'I don't know' or 'I can't recall' to close to a hundred questions" about the firings (most press reports counted 71 instances) and did not seem to know about the inner workings of his department. Gonzales responded that the onus was on the committee to prove whether anything improper occurred.
